Senator Joseph Sill Clark,
Democrat from Pennsylvania,
Will deliver a special talk in
Shriver Hall auditorium next
Friday, May 9, at 10 a.m., it was
announced this week by the Student Council.
Senator Clark's topic is "as
Yet unchosen," according to SC
assembly committee chairman
Don DeSantis, who added that
"we feel Senator Clark will give
a talk which is of interest to both
faculty and students."
Also at next Friday's assembly the Student Council will
Present gavels to four campus
leaders in recognition of their
service. Recipients of the award
Will be the incoming and outgoing presidents of both the Student Council and the senior class.
"This is the first time these
awards have been presented,
and we hope to make it an annual event," DeSantis explained.

While mayor of the City of
Brotherly Love Clark enacted
numerous reforms, including an
uprooting of the city police force,
dismantling of the patronage
racket and an upping of nearly
$20 million in taxes during his
first year.
Duff himself has termed Clark
"a left winger...(who) espouses
a totalitarian concept of government foreign to the American
constitutional system." At this
time the former senator was referring to Clark's participation
in the Americans for Democratic
Action.
In an article entitled,
"Wanted: Better Politicians,"
which appeared in the Atlantic
Monthly in 1955, Senator Clark
made plain his feeling that politics is a sagging American practice. He said: "I think we have
too much mediocrity in the business of running the government
of our country, and it troubles
me that this should be so at a
time of such complexity and
crisis."

lege, has been appointed Professor of History of Art and
Chairman of the Department of
Fine Arts at the Johns Hopkins
University, according to an announcement by Milton S. Eisenhower, President of Johns Hopkins.
Professor
Katzenellenbogen
came to the United States from
Germany, and has been on the
faculty of Vassar College since
1940 and since 1953 has been a
visiting member of the Institute
of Advanced Study in Princeton,
New Jersey. Since 1956 he has
been guest lecturer at Smith
College.
Well-known for his scholarly
work in late medieval and
early Renaissance arts, he was
educated in the universities of
Freiburg,
Leipzig,
Munich,
Frankfurt and Giessen. He received the degree of Doctor of
Jurisprudence from Giessen in
1924 and the degree of Doctor
of Philosophy from the University of Hamburg in 1933.

The Johns Hopkins Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa announced this week the election of two honorary members and 39 students.
Dr. Russell Morgan and
Dr. William L. Strauss, Jr.,
both of the medical institutions, were elected at the
annual business meeting on
Tuesday, April 22. Both

June Week To Boast
Dorsey, Count Basie

The Dixie Ballroom will be the
scene of this year's gala IFB
Formal dance, this Saturday,
May 3, from nine till one.
Very similar to previous IFB
formals, this Spring Formal will
include the music of Bob Craig
and his orchestra. The setting
will be cabaret style, with 50 to
60 round tables, each holding
about ten persons, set up and
reserved for individual fraternities.

The final touches are being
added to the plans for June
Week according to co-chairmen
Fred Rosenbloom and Lou Kady.
The Senior Prom, June 3, as
has been previously announcea,
will feature the band of Tommy
Dorsey under the direction of
Warren Covington. Thi3 dance
will kick off the week of exciting
events.
On June 4, the Annual Bull
Roast will be held at Bowley.s
Quarters. A large turnout is
hoped for as the roast is usually
one of the highpoints of the
week. The "Pier 5 Band" will be
there to keep things alive.
The "Count" Basie Band will
play June 5 for the Annual
Sports Dance at the Dixie Ballroom at the Gwynn Oak Amusement Park. Joe Williams, the
popular folk song singer, will be
present with the band.
The prices for all the events
will be the same as last year.
But since the quality has gone
up, the chairmen feel it is a
definite improvement. The announced prices are $11.50 for
seniors and $13.50 for undergraduates. These prices include
all the major events.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 3, 1958

Long Hits H. S. Teaching
In Parents' Day Address
In a short, emphatic address
to some one hundred students
and their parents, Dr. Clarence
D. Long, professor of political
economics and Democratic aspirant to the United States
Senate, attacked the quality of
teaching in American secondary
schools.
Dr. Long entitled his message
"Educational Opportunities for
the Youth of America". The bulk
of his address was devoted to
constructive criticism of our
educational system.
He first mentioned some of the
various purposes for education.
Of these, emphasis was placed
on: learning for earning's sake,
learning for social adjustment,
and learning for learning's sake.

Ginsberg Picks Assistants
For '58 Orientation Week
Orientation Week Chairman
Charlie Ginsberg announced his
assistants and staff for the 1958
program early this week.
Bill Sauer will be vice-chairman to Ginsberg; and other assistant chairmen are Warren
Donohue; Ray Poole, head of
the General Committee for
Orientation Week, and Pete

German Musicale
Features Soloists
Delta Phi Alpha, Hopkins honorary German fraternity, and
the Hopkins Goethe Society will
sponsor a concert of classical
music Friday, May 9, at 8:30 p.m.
in Shriver Hall.
The concert, which will be
open to all without charge, will
feature as soloists soprano Ruth
Moore, baritone Caspar Vacchione, and pianist Philip Eisenberg.
Music for the evening will consist chiefly of songs and arias
by such German composers as
Schumann, Brahms, Wolf, Wagner, Mozart and Richard Strauss.
A few selections by Verdi and
DeBussy will also be offered..
Miss Moore and Vecchione are
Baltimore artists who studied
at the Peabody Conservatory of
Music and are well known locally.
Eisenberg is a graduating Hopkins senior.

tional system. He pointed out
that a high correlation exists
between extent of education and
earning power.
Dr. Long stated also,"We have
not developed some of our best
minds for they have been drained
into other pursuits, particularly
in industry. Perhaps this is due
merely to the success of our educational system."
Learning for learning's sake
was at first too visionary and
impractical for our educational
system. As years passed, various
institutions of higher 1earn:1'2g
began to install facilities for
graduate study. Among the first
was the Johns Hopkins -University.
Pure academic study in the
United States was slow to develop mainly because America
was originally settled by the
working class of people, rather
than the aristocrats. It seems,
according to Dr. Long, that at
the time of the settlement of
America only the aristocratic
classes had time to think of
learning for learning's sake.
Dr. Long was particularlY
critical of the great expenditure
upon physical plants rather than
quality of education in America.
He suggested that physical expansion be delayed long enough
to bring the quality of educatiofl
up to the level of present quantity.
In order to illustrate the lack
of quality in education, Dr. Long
told the story of a high school
teacher who, for a period of at
least one semester, taught the
law of "Iminishing Returns" to
his class. It seems that the publisher of the text-book used in
the teacher's class had made a
typographical error, and since
the teacher evidently had no
other knowledge of this law, he
taught it as printed. Naturally,
the text should have read "the
law of Diminishing Returns."
Dr. Long strongly advocated
the increase of national economic resources spent on education. "In this way," said Dr.
Long, "We would be able to
make college available to everYbody who is able to take advantage of advanced educational
opportunities. We should make
college free like high school."

Steel Foundation this week as
part of a two million dollar
program designed "to provide
assistance to as many institutions as possible and to help
maintain the vigor of the leading
private institutions" in America's
educational system.

SWEENEY IN THE TREES
Spring is here—the season of tree-sitting contests. This I applaud. Tree-sitting is healthful and jolly and as American as
apple pie. Also it keeps you off the streets.
Tree-sitting is not, however, without its hazards. Take, for
example, the dread and chilling case of Manuel Sigafoos and
Ed Sweeney, both sophomores at the Nashville College of Folk
Music and Woodworking, and both madly in love with a beautiful alto named Ursula Thing, who won their hearts singing
that fine old folk song, I Strangled My True Love with Her Own
Yellow Braids, and I'll Never Eat Her Sorghum Any More.
Both Manuel and Ed pressed Ursula to go steady, but she
could not choose between them, and finally it was decided that
the boys would have a tree-sitting contest, and Ursula would
belong to the victor. So Manuel and Ed clambered up adjoining aspens, taking with them the following necessaries: food,
clothing, bedding, reading matter, and—most essential of all—
plenty of Marlboro Cigarettes.
We who live on the ground know how much you get to like
ith a Marlboro. Think how much more important they must
be to the lonely tree-dweller—how much more welcome their
fine, mild tobacco; how much more gratifying their free-drawing
filters; how much more comforting their sturdy, crushproof
flip-top box. Climb a tree and see for yourselves.

Students Catch Spring Fever,
Stage Yearly Goucher Raid
By NIELS SUNDERMEYER
and JOEL GORDON
Spring fever overcame a large
number of Hopkins students last
week as they staged the first
panty raid of the season at
Goucher College and then returned to put the area between
Gilman Hall and the dormitories
on the Homewood campus into a
state of calculated confusion.
The night-long 'spree, which
began with lively shouts amid
the dormitory buildings at approximately 10 p.m. Thursday
and died of sheer exhaustion at
4 o'clock Friday morning, involved groups as large as 80strong and as small as five.
After a minor uprising earlier
in the week had been smothered
by a heavy rainfall, the "bfg
push" came Thursday night
after some haphazard planning
resulted in the gathering of almost 100 Hopkins students,
almost all dormitory residents,
near the dorm parking lot to
form a convoy of cars to the
Goucher campus.
Setting out at approximately

10:15 p.m., the convoy met with
no opposition until it reached
the Goucher campus. Obviously
forewarned by an informer, a
Goucher campus policeman had
blocked the main entrance with
a paddy wagon and brilliant red
flare. After inspecting each car
with a flashlight, he told each
driver in no uncertain terms to
"get on back and don't try anything."
However, as evidenced by the
van -colored filmy trophies later
displayed by a large number of
Hopkins residents, the onslaught
was not quite so unsuccessful as
hoped. A number of excited
students told how, after parking
their cars, they had approached
the
campus
undiscovered
through
wooded
areas and
reached the dormitories, gaining
entrance by breaking windows
or pushing through doors
"It was easy," exclaimed one
of the raiders, later brandishing
his prize with leopard-skin pattern and the head of a tiger
glaring stoically from the front.
He reported that he and many
of his cohorts were readily admitted through dormitory win-

dows by "anxious and willing"
"Some
of
females.
them
screamed, but most of them
didn't mind. They knew about
it beforehand," he said.

'Stormers Save Year
With 'Charley's Aunt'

>

isb"A 77W.E SITTING CONTESIrs,
Well supplied with Marlboros, our heroes began their treesitting contest—Manuel with good heart, Ed with evil cunning.
The shocking fact is that crafty Ed,all unbeknownst to Manuel,
was one of three identical triplets. Each night while Manuel
dozed on his bough, one of Ed's brothers—Fred or Jed—would
sneak up the tree and replace him. "How can I lose?" said Ed
with a fiendish giggle to his brother Fred or Jed.
But Ed had a big surprise coming. For Manuel, though
he did not know it himself, was a druid! He had been abandoned
as an infant at the hut of a poor and humble woodcutter named
Cornelius Whitney Sigafoos III, who had raised the child as
his own. So when Manuel got into the tree, he found much to
his surprise that he had never in all his life felt so at home
and happy. He had absolutely no intention of ever leaving.
After seven or eight years Ed and his brothers wearied of the
contest and conceded. Ursula Thing came to NIanuel's tree
and cried, "I am yours! Come down and pin me!!
But Manuel declined. Instead he asked Ursula to join him
in the tree. This she could not do, being subject to mopery
(a morbid allergy to woodpeckers), so she ended up with Ed
after all.
Only she made a mistake—a very natural mistake. It was
Jed, not Ed, with whom she ended Up.
Ed, heartbroken at being tricked by his own brother, took
up metallurgy to forget.
Crime does not pay.

Almost 80 students reportedly
spent almost an hour in the girls
dormitories, during which" a lot
of property was either taken or
broken," according to one student. When city police arrived
and discovered the invaders, "we
decided to leave, and fast," another commented.
Several Hopkins students were
reportedly caught and taken to
police headquarters. Others described their narrow escapes. "I
was hailed by one of the cops
and asked what I was doing. I
said I had just come out to meet
a buddy who had taken his girl
home. Thank heavens he didn't
see my muddy shoes," a student
explained.
Hopkins Overrun
Meanwhile a similar line of
destructive pranks were taking
place right on the Homewood
campus. A series of concentrated
efforts by a comparatively small
group of Hopkins students resulted in complete disruption of
the area between Gilman Hall
and the dormitories.
One of the participants in
Friday's early-morning shncligs
at Homewood gave this report:
"The whole thing was a spurof-the moment affair, The only
thing we planned were the zeeds.
Somebody got the idea while
watching the tractor plow up the
lawns in front of the dorms to
plant a garden where grass was
supposed to grow. We bought
three dollars worth of garden
seeds .. . enough to start a
jungle. There were petunias,
radishes, sunflowers, gourds,
onions, and God knows what
else. We expect a victory garden
in thirty days.
"After that we decided to foul up the construction work in
front of Homewood House. With
about five guys, we pushed the
compressor into the ditch. Then
we set to work on the power
shovel. After hot-wring it we
drove it up the steps of Gilman
Hall. A lot of guys thought that
was pretty funny.

Barnstormer Finale A Success
By PAUL BERMAN
Last week the Hopkins community witnessed the final Barnstormer production of the current season. Charley's Aunt,
Brandon Thomas' popular theatrical warhorse, served to redeem the Barnstormers from
what would otherwise have been
a season fraught with poor productions.
At the risk of filling this review with superlatives, I must
admit that the production was
excellent. The acting was, without exception, quite good. The
sets, which were magnificently
executed, bore witness to the
hard work and time which went
into their construction.
Plays To The Hilt
The overall success of the play,
however, I would attribute to the
direction by Lester Wolf. He is
a master of the "light touch"
and is particularly successful
in directing comedy. His many
years of acting and directing experience in the field of comedy
enabled him to make the element
of slapstick, with which the play
abounds, artful. I feel that without Mr. Wolf's guiding hand, the
temptation to play up crudity
and slapstick would have proven
too much for the Barnstormers
to handle.
Michael Dale, incoming president of the Barnstormers, was
much more relaxed and animated
in the role of Jack Chesney than

he had been in his lamentable
performance in Doctor's Dilemma a couple of months ago. Dennis Donahue, as Charley, did
everything the role demanded of
him. Dan Tracy, as Brasset (not
Brassety, gentlemen) was con-

vincing.
David Hochberg, as Charley's
aunt, complete with long black
dress and wig, played his part to
the hilt. His very expressive face
and his ability to do a "double
take" greatly enhanced his performance. We particularly enjoyed the fiendish gleam in his
eye when, in accepting a rose
from one of his "admirers", he
proclaimed, "I'll have it stuffed!"
Mary Scheller, Mary Waesche,
John Gartland, Bill Bevans,
Nancy Berendt, and Pat Lynch
were the other members of this
fine cast.
Applaud Proposal
Perhaps the finest tribute to
the acting ability of the Barnstormers came during the scene
between Michael Dale and Mary
Scheller. Jack, having gotten
Kitty alone, finally stammers
out a marriage proposal. When
he finally got all the words out
and kissed Kitty, the audience
burst into spontaneous applause.
The actors had succeeded in getting the audience to empathize
with the characters on stage.
The Barnstormers may be very
proud of having closed the season

With a good show.

"Played Switch"
"After that we got lumber
from the construction and built
a rail fence across the road.
When a car came up we ran, and
I lost a loafer. But it was only a
couple of seniors. We then
started playing switch with the
cars in the parking lot."
"All the cars with unlocked
doors were in trouble, because it
was easy to release the emergency brake and push them. Two
were pushed to the entrance of
the lot so it was blocked off
completely. Another car was exchanged for fifteen milk cans
which we lined up on the wall
in front of the old dorms."
"Next we pushed a Nash up to
the new dorms, hoping to get it
into the Snack Bar. It wouldn't
fit, so we left it blocking the
main door. Finally we left some
lounge furniture on the lawn
looking like an abandoned tea
party, and decorated the tee&
with toilet paper.
"It was about 4 o'clock and
getting light, so we broke up. I
went to my room, showered, and
sacked out until lunch."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 3, 1958

Alumni Coming Home
With Cheers, Booze
"Plans are well under way for
the 1958 Alumni Homecoming,"
according to Osmar P. Steinwald, Director of Alumni Relations.
The list of events begins on
Friday May 16 with the Johns
Hopkins Engineers Annual Dinner in Levering Hall. Dr. John
Strong, the after-dinner speaker,
Will talk on "Getting Ready for
Mars."
On Saturday, May 17, the
Alumni will gather in Shriver
Hall to Hear Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower moderate a symposium on
the topic, "An Intimate Report
on New Developments at Johns
Hopkins."

Medallions to the class of 1908
will take place on the Homewood
field. It is hoped that at least
20 members of the fifty-year-old
class will be present to receive
their awards.
After the Hopkins-Maryland
Lacrosse game, the
visiting
alumni will visit the fraternity
open houses and then go to
their respective class reunion
dinners held at various places
on the campus and throughout
the city. At 9:00 p.m. they will
take part in the Starlighter
Dance to be held on the Gilman
Terrace.

close.

made the following statement:
"Initially, every reported violation will be handled by the
Judicial Committee. Upon recommendation by the committee,
trials will be held.
Four Problems
"The importance of this is
that the bulk of the work is
handled by the committee, allowing the Board to deal with other
extant business, leading to greater expediency generally facilitating the functioning of the
Board."
Broening also outlined four
major
problems facing
the
Board and how he proposes to
deal with them: "Our problems
are, first, financial stability,
which has already been effected;
second, proper orientation of
freshmen with respect to the
fraternity system and effective
administration of the new rules
governing rushing activities.
"Third, if possible, we hope

to promote fraternity-neighbor
amity in general; fourth, reorganize 11ei3 representation to
include fraternity presidents."
Render Unto The IFB ...

ordinance which would abolish drinking at all fraternity
houses, Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, Dean of the Homewood
Schools, stated: "As a group
responsible for its own affairs,
so the IFB must deal with its
own problems in face of organ..
ized opposition."
Broening asserted the IFB's
ability to assume such by saying
that the Board "is both willing
and able to assume its responsibilities."

Under the new rules all fraternity violations will be reported to the chairman of the

will report violations to the IFB
president, and "all violations reported shall be construed as an

a second violation he will be
blacklisted until the nezt rush
season."

specifying if each violation is of

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE TWO

June Week To Boast
Dorsey, Count Basie

The Dixie Ballroom will be the
scene of this year's gala IFB
Formal dance, this Saturday,
May 3, from nine till one.
Very similar to previous IFB
formals, this Spring Formal will
include the music of Bob Craig
and his orchestra. The setting
will be cabaret style, with 50 to
60 round tables, each holding
about ten persons, set up and
reserved for individual fraternities.

The final touches are being
added to the plans for June
Week according to co-chairmen
Fred Rosenbloom and Lou Kady.
The Senior Prom, June 3, as
has been previously announcea,
will feature the band of Tommy
Dorsey under the direction of
Warren Covington. Thi3 dance
will kick off the week of exciting
events.
On June 4, the Annual Bull
Roast will be held at Bowley.s
Quarters. A large turnout is
hoped for as the roast is usually
one of the highpoints of the
week. The "Pier 5 Band" will be
there to keep things alive.
The "Count" Basie Band will
play June 5 for the Annual
Sports Dance at the Dixie Ballroom at the Gwynn Oak Amusement Park. Joe Williams, the
popular folk song singer, will be
present with the band.
The prices for all the events
will be the same as last year.
But since the quality has gone

constructive criticism of our

various purposes for education.

on: learning for earning's sake,
learning for social adjustment,

Ginsberg Picks Assistants
For '58 Orientation Week
Orientation Week Chairman
Charlie Ginsberg announced his
assistants and staff for the 1958
program early this week.
Bill Sauer will be vice-chairman to Ginsberg; and other assistant chairmen are Warren
Donohue; Ray Poole, head of
the General Committee for
Orientation Week, and Pete

German Musicale
Features Soloists
Delta Phi Alpha, Hopkins honorary German fraternity, and
the Hopkins Goethe Society will
sponsor a concert of classical
music Friday, May 9, at 8:30 p.m.
in Shriver Hall.
The concert, which will be
open to all without charge, will
feature as soloists soprano Ruth
Moore, baritone Caspar Vacchione, and pianist Philip Eisenberg.
Music for the evening will consist chiefly of songs and arias
by such German composers as
Schumann, Brahms, Wolf, Wagner, Mozart and Richard Strauss.
A few selections by Verdi and
DeBussy will also be offered..
Miss Moore and Vecchione are
Baltimore artists who studied
at the Peabody Conservatory of
Music and are well known locally.
Eisenberg is a graduating Hopkins senior.

tional system. He pointed out
that a high correlation exists
between extent of education and
earning power.
Dr. Long stated also,"We have
not developed some of our best
minds for they have been drained
into other pursuits, particularly
in industry. Perhaps this is due
merely to the success of our educational system."
Learning for learning's sake
was at first too visionary and
impractical for our educational
system. As years passed, various
institutions of higher 1earn:1'2g
began to install facilities for
graduate study. Among the first
was the Johns Hopkins -University.
Pure academic study in the
United States was slow to develop mainly because America
was originally settled by the
working class of people, rather
than the aristocrats. It seems,
according to Dr. Long, that at
the time of the settlement of
America only the aristocratic
classes had time to think of
learning for learning's sake.
Dr. Long was particularlY
critical of the great expenditure
upon physical plants rather than
quality of education in America.
He suggested that physical expansion be delayed long enough
to bring the quality of educatiofl
up to the level of present quantity.
In order to illustrate the lack
of quality in education, Dr. Long
told the story of a high school
teacher who, for a period of at
least one semester, taught the
law of "Iminishing Returns" to
his class. It seems that the publisher of the text-book used in
the teacher's class had made a
typographical error, and since
the teacher evidently had no
other knowledge of this law, he
taught it as printed. Naturally,
the text should have read "the
law of Diminishing Returns."
Dr. Long strongly advocated
the increase of national economic resources spent on education. "In this way," said Dr.
Long, "We would be able to
make college available to everYbody who is able to take advantage of advanced educational
opportunities. We should make
college free like high school."

Spring is here—the season of tree-sitting contests. This I applaud. Tree-sitting is healthful and jolly and as American as
apple pie. Also it keeps you off the streets.
Tree-sitting is not, however, without its hazards. Take, for
example, the dread and chilling case of Manuel Sigafoos and
Ed Sweeney, both sophomores at the Nashville College of Folk
Music and Woodworking, and both madly in love with a beautiful alto named Ursula Thing, who won their hearts singing
that fine old folk song, I Strangled My True Love with Her Own
Yellow Braids, and I'll Never Eat Her Sorghum Any More.
Both Manuel and Ed pressed Ursula to go steady, but she
could not choose between them, and finally it was decided that
the boys would have a tree-sitting contest, and Ursula would
belong to the victor. So Manuel and Ed clambered up adjoining aspens, taking with them the following necessaries: food,
clothing, bedding, reading matter, and—most essential of all—
plenty of Marlboro Cigarettes.
We who live on the ground know how much you get to like
ith a Marlboro. Think how much more important they must
be to the lonely tree-dweller—how much more welcome their
fine, mild tobacco; how much more gratifying their free-drawing
filters; how much more comforting their sturdy, crushproof
flip-top box. Climb a tree and see for yourselves.

Students Catch Spring Fever,
Stage Yearly Goucher Raid
By NIELS SUNDERMEYER
and JOEL GORDON
Spring fever overcame a large
number of Hopkins students last
week as they staged the first
panty raid of the season at
Goucher College and then returned to put the area between
Gilman Hall and the dormitories
on the Homewood campus into a
state of calculated confusion.
The night-long 'spree, which
began with lively shouts amid
the dormitory buildings at approximately 10 p.m. Thursday
and died of sheer exhaustion at
4 o'clock Friday morning, involved groups as large as 80strong and as small as five.
After a minor uprising earlier
in the week had been smothered
by a heavy rainfall, the "bfg
push" came Thursday night
after some haphazard planning
resulted in the gathering of almost 100 Hopkins students,
almost all dormitory residents,
near the dorm parking lot to
form a convoy of cars to the
Goucher campus.
Setting out at approximately

10:15 p.m., the convoy met with
no opposition until it reached
the Goucher campus. Obviously
forewarned by an informer, a
Goucher campus policeman had
blocked the main entrance with
a paddy wagon and brilliant red
flare. After inspecting each car
with a flashlight, he told each
driver in no uncertain terms to
"get on back and don't try anything."
However, as evidenced by the
van -colored filmy trophies later
displayed by a large number of
Hopkins residents, the onslaught
was not quite so unsuccessful as
hoped. A number of excited
students told how, after parking
their cars, they had approached
the
campus
undiscovered
through
wooded
areas and
reached the dormitories, gaining
entrance by breaking windows
or pushing through doors
"It was easy," exclaimed one
of the raiders, later brandishing
his prize with leopard-skin pattern and the head of a tiger
glaring stoically from the front.
He reported that he and many
of his cohorts were readily admitted through dormitory win-

dows by "anxious and willing"
"Some
of
females.

screamed, but most of them
didn't mind. They knew about
it beforehand," he said.

'Stormers Save Year
With 'Charley's Aunt'

>

isb"A 77W.E SITTING CONTESIrs,
Well supplied with Marlboros, our heroes began their treesitting contest—Manuel with good heart, Ed with evil cunning.
The shocking fact is that crafty Ed,all unbeknownst to Manuel,
was one of three identical triplets. Each night while Manuel
dozed on his bough, one of Ed's brothers—Fred or Jed—would
sneak up the tree and replace him. "How can I lose?" said Ed
with a fiendish giggle to his brother Fred or Jed.
But Ed had a big surprise coming. For Manuel, though
he did not know it himself, was a druid! He had been abandoned
as an infant at the hut of a poor and humble woodcutter named
Cornelius Whitney Sigafoos III, who had raised the child as
his own. So when Manuel got into the tree, he found much to
his surprise that he had never in all his life felt so at home
and happy. He had absolutely no intention of ever leaving.
After seven or eight years Ed and his brothers wearied of the
contest and conceded. Ursula Thing came to NIanuel's tree
and cried, "I am yours! Come down and pin me!!
But Manuel declined. Instead he asked Ursula to join him
in the tree. This she could not do, being subject to mopery
(a morbid allergy to woodpeckers), so she ended up with Ed
after all.
Only she made a mistake—a very natural mistake. It was
Jed, not Ed, with whom she ended Up.
Ed, heartbroken at being tricked by his own brother, took
up metallurgy to forget.
Crime does not pay.

Almost 80 students reportedly
spent almost an hour in the girls
dormitories, during which" a lot
of property was either taken or
broken," according to one student. When city police arrived
and discovered the invaders, "we
decided to leave, and fast," another commented.
Several Hopkins students were
reportedly caught and taken to
police headquarters. Others described their narrow escapes. "I
was hailed by one of the cops
and asked what I was doing. I
said I had just come out to meet
a buddy who had taken his girl
home. Thank heavens he didn't
see my muddy shoes," a student
explained.
Hopkins Overrun
Meanwhile a similar line of
destructive pranks were taking
place right on the Homewood
campus. A series of concentrated
efforts by a comparatively small
group of Hopkins students resulted in complete disruption of
the area between Gilman Hall
and the dormitories.
One of the participants in
Friday's early-morning shncligs
at Homewood gave this report:
"The whole thing was a spurof-the moment affair, The only
thing we planned were the zeeds.
Somebody got the idea while
watching the tractor plow up the
lawns in front of the dorms to
plant a garden where grass was
supposed to grow. We bought
three dollars worth of garden
seeds .. . enough to start a
jungle. There were petunias,
radishes, sunflowers, gourds,
onions, and God knows what
else. We expect a victory garden
in thirty days.
"After that we decided to foul up the construction work in
front of Homewood House. With
about five guys, we pushed the
compressor into the ditch. Then
we set to work on the power
shovel. After hot-wring it we
drove it up the steps of Gilman
Hall. A lot of guys thought that
was pretty funny.

Barnstormer Finale A Success
By PAUL BERMAN
Last week the Hopkins community witnessed the final Barnstormer production of the current season. Charley's Aunt,
Brandon Thomas' popular theatrical warhorse, served to redeem the Barnstormers from
what would otherwise have been
a season fraught with poor productions.
At the risk of filling this review with superlatives, I must
admit that the production was
excellent. The acting was, without exception, quite good. The
sets, which were magnificently
executed, bore witness to the
hard work and time which went
into their construction.
Plays To The Hilt
The overall success of the play,
however, I would attribute to the
direction by Lester Wolf. He is
a master of the "light touch"
and is particularly successful
in directing comedy. His many
years of acting and directing experience in the field of comedy
enabled him to make the element
of slapstick, with which the play
abounds, artful. I feel that without Mr. Wolf's guiding hand, the
temptation to play up crudity
and slapstick would have proven
too much for the Barnstormers
to handle.
Michael Dale, incoming president of the Barnstormers, was
much more relaxed and animated
in the role of Jack Chesney than

he had been in his lamentable
performance in Doctor's Dilemma a couple of months ago. Dennis Donahue, as Charley, did
everything the role demanded of
him. Dan Tracy, as Brasset (not
Brassety, gentlemen) was con-

vincing.
David Hochberg, as Charley's
aunt, complete with long black
dress and wig, played his part to
the hilt. His very expressive face
and his ability to do a "double
take" greatly enhanced his performance. We particularly enjoyed the fiendish gleam in his
eye when, in accepting a rose
from one of his "admirers", he
proclaimed, "I'll have it stuffed!"
Mary Scheller, Mary Waesche,
John Gartland, Bill Bevans,
Nancy Berendt, and Pat Lynch
were the other members of this
fine cast.
Applaud Proposal
Perhaps the finest tribute to
the acting ability of the Barnstormers came during the scene
between Michael Dale and Mary
Scheller. Jack, having gotten
Kitty alone, finally stammers
out a marriage proposal. When
he finally got all the words out
and kissed Kitty, the audience
burst into spontaneous applause.
The actors had succeeded in getting the audience to empathize
with the characters on stage.
The Barnstormers may be very
proud of having closed the season

With a good show.

"Played Switch"
"After that we got lumber
from the construction and built
a rail fence across the road.
When a car came up we ran, and
I lost a loafer. But it was only a
couple of seniors. We then
started playing switch with the
cars in the parking lot."
"All the cars with unlocked
doors were in trouble, because it
was easy to release the emergency brake and push them. Two
were pushed to the entrance of
the lot so it was blocked off
completely. Another car was exchanged for fifteen milk cans
which we lined up on the wall
in front of the old dorms."
"Next we pushed a Nash up to
the new dorms, hoping to get it
into the Snack Bar. It wouldn't
fit, so we left it blocking the
main door. Finally we left some
lounge furniture on the lawn
looking like an abandoned tea
party, and decorated the tee&
with toilet paper.
"It was about 4 o'clock and
getting light, so we broke up. I
went to my room, showered, and
sacked out until lunch."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 3, 1958

Alumni Coming Home
With Cheers, Booze
"Plans are well under way for
the 1958 Alumni Homecoming,"
according to Osmar P. Steinwald, Director of Alumni Relations.
The list of events begins on
Friday May 16 with the Johns
Hopkins Engineers Annual Dinner in Levering Hall. Dr. John
Strong, the after-dinner speaker,
Will talk on "Getting Ready for
Mars."
On Saturday, May 17, the
Alumni will gather in Shriver
Hall to Hear Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower moderate a symposium on
the topic, "An Intimate Report
on New Developments at Johns
Hopkins."

Medallions to the class of 1908
will take place on the Homewood
field. It is hoped that at least
20 members of the fifty-year-old
class will be present to receive
their awards.
After the Hopkins-Maryland
Lacrosse game, the
visiting
alumni will visit the fraternity
open houses and then go to
their respective class reunion
dinners held at various places
on the campus and throughout
the city. At 9:00 p.m. they will
take part in the Starlighter
Dance to be held on the Gilman
Terrace.

During the afternoon the anOn Sunday the Branch Asnual Parade of Classes and the sociation Presidents will hold

the weekend's activities to a
close.

this will be the largest homecoming we have ever had, with

IFB President Steve Broening
made the following statement:
"Initially, every reported violation will be handled by the
Judicial Committee. Upon recommendation by the committee,
trials will be held.
Four Problems
"The importance of this is
that the bulk of the work is
handled by the committee, allowing the Board to deal with other
extant business, leading to greater expediency generally facilitating the functioning of the
Board."
Broening also outlined four
major
problems facing
the
Board and how he proposes to
deal with them: "Our problems
are, first, financial stability,
which has already been effected;
second, proper orientation of
freshmen with respect to the
fraternity system and effective
administration of the new rules
governing rushing activities.
"Third, if possible, we hope

to promote fraternity-neighbor
amity in general; fourth, reorganize 11ei3 representation to
include fraternity presidents."
Render Unto The IFB ...
Regarding the proposed city
ordinance which would abolish drinking at all fraternity
houses, Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, Dean of the Homewood
Schools, stated: "As a group
responsible for its own affairs,
so the IFB must deal with its
own problems in face of organ..
ized opposition."
Broening asserted the IFB's
ability to assume such by saying
that the Board "is both willing
and able to assume its responsibilities."

The new rush rules state, in
part: "A Judicial Committee is
to be appointed by the President
with Board approval. This committee will be composed of a
chairman, four members, and
two alternates, the chairman
being the Board vice-president.
The Judicial Committee of the
Board as a whole will hold trials
when deemed necessary."
Changes In Penalties
Under the new rules all fraternity violations will be reported to the chairman of the
Judiciary Committee. Rushees
will report violations to the IFB
president, and "all violations reported shall be construed as an
accusation by an individual."
The rush rules also state
several changes in rushing penalties and blacklisting procedures:
"A rushee guilty of a major
violation as determined by the
Judicial Committee shall be forbidden to pledge the fraternity
with whom he participated in
this violation until the following
rush season. If found guilty of
a second violation he will be
blacklisted until the nezt rush
season."
Major Or Minor?
According to the new rules,
the Judicial Committee must
report to the Board in toto,
specifying if each violation is of
major or minor character.
The rules also state: "Any fraternity guilty of a major violation shall be fined . . . for the
first offense an amount of at
least $50." For second offense
